image_list.story_html:
Eric was an outgoing, open-minded, cheerful friend. He loved music and we had many good times, going to concerts, hanging out down by the river, always drinking and smoking.

When punk rock came along he was — unlike some of my friends — open to the newer sounds. Ultimately, though, Cat Stevens was his favorite artist.

He had a great laugh and was hard-working and smart, but after completing high school, had no interest in furthering his education. As we grew older and less resilient to the after effects of partying, most of us learned how to abstain or at least moderate. Eric was one exception to this general trend I saw among my friends and in myself, as we grew into our thirties and beyond.

At one point he read some Nietzsche. This seemed to fuel his drinking and make him more apathetic about life in general and the future in particular. Ultimately he became a very tragic figure.

Eric passed away on November 26, 2016. His spirit was as unique as this portrait of it, and I am glad to have this image of his personality to remember him by.

image_list.story_html:
Bob and I have been friends for so long, I don't remember how we met. We went to a lot of concerts together in the 1970s and 80s.

Roommate Backlash and Musical Snobbery

At the time, I had friends who harbored a lot of prejudice against certain types of music. It was a pretty huge thing, a person could actually lose friends for being a non-conformist and listening to the wrong bands.

This could be particularly bad when one roommate subjected another to music they did not care for. For awhile, thanks to this sort of roommate backlash, I developed my own brand of musical snobbery — in favor of American music and against British music.

Rock Concerts in the '70s and '80s

Back then Bob and I would go to these concerts along with as many of our friends as we could get to join us. Rock 'n' roll was huge back then, and we loved going to see bands like The Grateful Dead, The Who, and Little Feat.

In those days, before the internet, getting tickets could be tricky, because they had to be purchased in person or over the phone. This meant finding out when and where they went on sale, and quite possibly waiting in line or repeatedly dialing a certain number and hoping to get through somehow. It could be extremely difficult to get tickets to very popular acts such as The Rolling Stones.

Want to See The Stones?

I vividly remember the night we saw Little Feat at the best venue in town at the time, the Mosque — now known as the Altria Theater. Bob and I were talking about other upcoming concerts, and he asked if I'd like to go to see The Stones.

Right away I said nah, but after awhile started thinking, I'd never met anyone — except Bob, apparently — who had ever been to a Stones concert. In fact, getting tickets for such a popular show seemed impossible!

Bob had been to a few of their shows, so he knew how to get tickets. He somehow managed to come through and we went to Stones concert at JFK Stadium in Philadelphia, PA in the summer of 1978.

As mentioned above, at that time I was a little down on British music. I would call it more of a preference for American musicians than I would a hatred of the Brits — but hate is not too strong a word for how some people at that time felt about music they didn't like.

We Were So Much Older Then —
We're Younger Than That Now

It may seem strange in this new millennium, but in Richmond, VA back in the 1970s and 80s some music lovers had very strong opinions about their music. There were even tales of fist fights between people who loved country music and those who loved punk rock!

In those days I was an amateur musician. I had played trumpet and taken a class in music theory in high school, and taught myself how to play guitar and bass after graduation.

I was in it only for the fun, and had played a little classical and jazz. I quickly learned that a lot of popular music — country, bluegrass, folk, blues, rock, and the like — is based on only three chords.

Also back then I was also a big fan of both science fiction and bluegrass, but considered them to be totally unrelated. They were just two of the things I was into at the time.

At the Show

Finally, the big day arrived and a group of us traveled up to JFK Stadium Philadelphia on June 17, 1978 to see the show we'd been looking forward to for so long.

I started out feeling a bit cynical about the band. Why were they so popular? I didn't get it.

There were so many other musicians — especially classical and jazz musicians — that were much more technically proficient. It seemed unfair that these guys could make so much money, apparently just by goofing around and being bad boys, while others who were hard-working professionals remained poor by comparison.

Bluegrass Meets Science Fiction!?!

Then during one song I saw Keith Richards using a capo — a contraption that was very popular among country and bluegrass musicians, because it allowed them to easily play the three chords in different keys.

This gave me a sudden flash of insight: The Rolling Stones were like science fiction bluegrass! The Stones played the same three chords as any bluegrass band, the difference was they were from different time periods.

A Life-Altering Experience

The concert suddenly became a life-altering experience, and I decided that being prejudiced against certain types of music was not just silly but totally self-defeating. Today most people seem to feel similarly open-minded — albeit all too often open to all music except for country. Well, whatever.

This new-found open-mindedness enabled me to thoroughly enjoy the punk rock and new wave bands through the late 1970s and 80s, and ultimately served me well as I explored other art forms. In the decades since then I've enjoyed learning about photography, the visual arts, all genres and types of movies and tv shows, and even dancing!

One of the most important lessons out of this entire journey was learning about Wassily Kandinsky's triangle — but that is a different story.

Shattered

I will never forget that show, and have Bob to thank for what turned out to be a profound, unique, once-in-a-lifetime experience! I remember the song Shattered, in particular, made a big impression on me for some reason.

For a taste of what it was like in Philly that day, there is a collection of excellent photos of the fans at the show posted online, and below is the official video of the song Shattered for the tour:

Bob lives in Powhatan, Virginia. He went to school at University of Colorado in Boulder.

When I wrote the original version of the Groja © Program in college in Richmond, Virginia, I was very interested in Libertarianism. During that time I was able to get Roy B. Scherer to answer the questions in the Keirsey Temperament Sorter. Roy is still a Libertarian who continues to lobby in Richmond Virginia for gun rights and the legalization of marijuana.

Here is an image of his personality. One might think that marijuana legalization would be a passionate issue, but his portrait shows that, for him at least, it was largely a matter of logic.
